body_text.text: E. Historical movement: Not known, but following the initial isolation in Canada (13), the virus was reported from the United Kingdom (2), United States (11), Western Europe (4, 8, 12, 15) , Australia (6), and Japan (9) . To day in Canada the virus is endemic and antibodies can be demonstrated, but the disease syndrome is no longer evident (5).

FIGREF0.text: Porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus. Shaded areas = Documented. Porcine Hemagglutinating Encephalomyelitis Virus A. Classification and description: Family, Coronaviridae; genus, Coro navirus; species, Porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus (HEV). It causes two distinct syndromes. One is known as vomiting and wasting disease and the other involves an encephalomyelitis. B. Host: Pigs. C. Areas free of the virus: Unknown. D. Key developments: Vomiting and wasting disease (13) and encepha lomyelitis (1) were initially reported as two separate diseases in Canada in the late 1950s. The virus was isolated in 1962(7)and the common etiology of the two syndromes was shown in 1969(3).

FIGREF1.text: . Diagnostic techniques: HI(10,14,15), VN(10,14), and AGID(10)have all been reported. G. Diagnostic reagents: See Section F. H. Map credits: Current literature. I. Key references:
